<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 118, 379, 144]]<|/det|>
# Cambridge IGCSE™  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 170, 183, 187]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 194, 332, 210]]<|/det|>
Paper 1 Multiple Choice (Core)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[784, 170, 905, 186]]<|/det|>
0625/11  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[784, 194, 905, 210]]<|/det|>
May/June 2020  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[814, 217, 905, 232]]<|/det|>
45 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 247, 507, 264]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the multiple choice answer sheet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 278, 437, 293]]<|/det|>
You will need: Multiple choice answer sheet  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[215, 293, 539, 322]]<|/det|>
Soft clean eraser Soft pencil (type B or HB is recommended)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 338, 227, 353]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 354, 115, 369]]<|/det|>
<label>?</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 354, 598, 370]]<|/det|>
There are forty questions on this paper. Answer all questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 370, 907, 400]]<|/det|>
For each question there are four possible answers \(\mathbf{A}\) , \(\mathbf{B}\) , \(\mathbf{C}\) and \(\mathbf{D}\) . Choose the one you consider correct and record your choice in soft pencil on the multiple choice answer sheet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 400, 578, 415]]<|/det|>
Follow the instructions on the multiple choice answer sheet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 416, 277, 431]]<|/det|>
Write in soft pencil.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 431, 868, 462]]<|/det|>
Write your name, centre number and candidate number on the multiple choice answer sheet in the spaces provided unless this has been done for you.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 462, 330, 476]]<|/det|>
Do not use correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 477, 364, 492]]<|/det|>
Do not write on any bar codes.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 492, 329, 507]]<|/det|>
You may use a calculator.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 507, 672, 523]]<|/det|>
Take the weight of \(1.0\mathrm{kg}\) to be \(10\mathrm{N}\) (acceleration of free fall \(= 10\mathrm{m / s}^2\) ).  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 550, 220, 564]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 566, 391, 581]]<|/det|>
The total mark for this paper is 40.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 581, 806, 597]]<|/det|>
Each correct answer will score one mark. A mark will not be deducted for a wrong answer.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 597, 571, 613]]<|/det|>
Any rough working should be done on this question paper.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 99, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 72, 556, 91]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 102, 495, 121]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 129, 134, 148]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 129, 193, 148]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 129, 303, 148]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[311, 129, 361, 148]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[475, 129, 527, 148]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 562, 539, 580]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 588, 131, 606]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 588, 556, 606]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 615, 816, 633]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 96, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 774, 89]]<|/det|> The diagram shows part of a rollercoaster ride with the car at different positions. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 102, 828, 119]]<|/det|> The car runs freely down from position X to position Y and up the hill on the other side. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[242, 131, 756, 322]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 338, 922, 371]]<|/det|> What happens to the kinetic energy and to the gravitational potential energy of the car as it moves from position X to position Y? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 382, 534, 529]]<|/det|>
kinetic energygravitational potential energy
Adecreasesdecreases
Bdecreasesincreases
Cincreasesdecreases
Dincreasesincreases
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 555, 104, 573]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 555, 672, 573]]<|/det|> Student P uses a force of \(35\mathrm{N}\) to push a box \(3.0\mathrm{m}\) across the floor. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 585, 725, 603]]<|/det|> Student Q uses a force of \(22\mathrm{N}\) to push another box \(1.8\mathrm{m}\) across the floor. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 616, 863, 633]]<|/det|> Which statement gives a full explanation why student P uses more energy than student Q? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 644, 134, 662]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 644, 650, 662]]<|/det|> Student P pushes his box a greater distance than student Q. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 672, 134, 689]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 672, 848, 689]]<|/det|> Student P pushes his box a greater distance and uses a bigger force than student Q. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 698, 134, 715]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 698, 532, 715]]<|/det|> Student P uses a bigger force than student Q. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 724, 134, 742]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 724, 549, 742]]<|/det|> Student P pushes a heavier box than student Q.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 109, 88]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 809, 88]]<|/det|> A man can either take an escalator or a lift to travel up between two floors in a hotel. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[180, 100, 816, 380]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 393, 920, 426]]<|/det|> The escalator takes 20 seconds to carry the man between the two floors. The useful work done against gravity is \(W\). The useful power developed is \(P\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 438, 761, 456]]<|/det|> The lift takes 30 seconds to carry the same man between the same two floors. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 468, 920, 501]]<|/det|> How much useful work against gravity is done by the lift, and how much useful power is developed by the lift? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 512, 510, 675]]<|/det|>
useful work
done against
gravity by lift		useful power
developed by lift
Amore than \(W\)less than \(P\)
Bmore than \(W\)\(P\)
C\(W\)less than \(P\)
D\(W\)\(P\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 71, 922, 106]]<|/det|>
Four submarines are submerged. The density of fresh water is \(1000 \text{kg} /\text{m}^3\) and the density of sea water is \(1020 \text{kg} /\text{m}^3\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 116, 697, 135]]<|/det|>

<label>14</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 580, 428, 598]]<|/det|>
A gas is heated in a sealed container.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 610, 497, 628]]<|/det|>
The volume of the container does not change.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 640, 477, 658]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 668, 134, 686]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 723, 470, 740]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 106, 88]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 920, 104]]<|/det|> A student is investigating evaporation. She soaks a piece of cotton wool in a liquid and attaches this to the bulb of a thermometer. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 116, 767, 134]]<|/det|> As the liquid evaporates the temperature reading on the thermometer changes. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[212, 144, 784, 215]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 228, 348, 246]]<|/det|> Which statement is correct? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 256, 134, 275]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 256, 868, 274]]<|/det|> The more energetic molecules leave the liquid and the temperature reading decreases. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 282, 134, 301]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 282, 863, 300]]<|/det|> The more energetic molecules leave the liquid and the temperature reading increases. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 308, 134, 327]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 308, 861, 326]]<|/det|> The less energetic molecules leave the liquid and the temperature reading decreases. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 335, 134, 353]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 335, 853, 352]]<|/det|> The less energetic molecules leave the liquid and the temperature reading increases. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 380, 106, 397]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 380, 499, 397]]<|/det|> The thermometer in the diagram has no scale. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 409, 920, 443]]<|/det|> Before this thermometer can be used to measure temperature, two standard temperatures known as fixed points are needed. These are labelled X and Y. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 453, 532, 667]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 680, 621, 698]]<|/det|> Which row describes these fixed points on the Celsius scale? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 708, 836, 838]]<|/det|>
XY
Atemperature of pure boiling waternormal body temperature

Cnormal body temperaturetemperature of pure boiling water

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 107, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>17</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 609, 89]]<|/det|>
When a hot gas is left to cool, its internal energy decreases.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 102, 272, 120]]<|/det|>
What causes this?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 131, 133, 147]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 131, 579, 147]]<|/det|>
a decrease in the kinetic energy of the gas particles

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 157, 133, 175]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 156, 702, 175]]<|/det|>
a decrease in the gravitational potential energy of the gas particles

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 184, 131, 201]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 183, 591, 201]]<|/det|>
an increase in the average speed of the gas particles

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 210, 133, 227]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 208, 722, 227]]<|/det|>
an increase in the average distance of separation of the gas particles

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 254, 107, 272]]<|/det|>
<label>18</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 253, 808, 272]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 284, 609, 301]]<|/det|>
The same quantity of thermal energy is given to each block.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 313, 551, 331]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[171, 344, 195, 361]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[133, 371, 880, 476]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 500, 107, 518]]<|/det|>
<label>19</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 500, 920, 534]]<|/det|>
One ice cube is placed on a metal block. An identical ice cube is placed on a plastic block. The blocks are left next to each other on a table in a laboratory.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[319, 542, 680, 660]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 673, 415, 691]]<|/det|>
Which ice cube melts first and why?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 702, 134, 720]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 702, 920, 736]]<|/det|>
The ice cube on the plastic block melts first because plastic is a good insulator of thermal energy.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 744, 133, 761]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 744, 920, 778]]<|/det|>
The ice cube on the plastic block melts first because plastic is a good conductor of thermal energy.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 787, 133, 804]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 785, 920, 819]]<|/det|>
The ice cube on the metal block melts first because metal is a good conductor of thermal energy.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 828, 133, 845]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 826, 920, 860]]<|/det|>
The ice cube on the metal block melts first because metal is a good insulator of thermal energy.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 106, 88]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 72, 905, 104]]<|/det|> A conducting wire is placed between the poles of a magnet. When an electric current in the wire is in the direction shown, then the force on the wire acts out of the page. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[391, 114, 601, 201]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 218, 767, 237]]<|/det|> Three statements of different conditions and how the wire is affected are given. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 249, 203, 266]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[222, 248, 902, 282]]<|/det|> The current is towards the top of the page and the direction of the magnetic field is unchanged then the force produced acts into the page. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[185, 290, 203, 308]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[222, 289, 885, 323]]<|/det|> The current is towards the bottom of the page and the magnetic field is reversed then the force produced acts into the page. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[185, 330, 205, 348]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[222, 330, 902, 348]]<|/det|> The current in the wire is alternating and the wire vibrates into and out of the page. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 361, 371, 378]]<|/det|> Which statements are correct? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 388, 134, 406]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 388, 740, 406]]<|/det|> 1 and 2 only B 1 and 3 only C 2 and 3 only D 1, 2 and 3 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 433, 106, 451]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 433, 549, 451]]<|/det|> A nuclide of the element iron has the symbol shown. <|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[467, 467, 531, 500]]<|/det|> \[\frac{56}{26}\mathrm{Fe}\] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 515, 527, 533]]<|/det|> What does a neutral atom of this nuclide contain? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 545, 480, 675]]<|/det|>
protonsneutronselectrons
A263026
B265630
C302656
D562630
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 700, 106, 719]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 700, 462, 719]]<|/det|> What is the nucleon number of a nuclide? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 730, 133, 748]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 730, 467, 748]]<|/det|> the number of neutrons in the nucleus <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 757, 133, 775]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 757, 457, 775]]<|/det|> the number of protons in the nucleus <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 784, 133, 802]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 784, 707, 801]]<|/det|> the number of protons minus the number of neutrons in the nucleus <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 810, 133, 828]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 810, 692, 828]]<|/det|> the number of protons plus the number of neutrons in the nucleus

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 106, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>39</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
A thin sheet of paper is placed between a radioactive source and a radiation detector. The count rate falls to a very low reading.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[316, 114, 680, 234]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 248, 633, 268]]<|/det|>
From this result, which type of radiation is the source emitting?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 279, 141, 297]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 280, 243, 297]]<|/det|>
\(\alpha\) -particles

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 306, 138, 324]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 306, 243, 324]]<|/det|>

X-rays

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 404, 104, 421]]<|/det|>
<label>40</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 402, 749, 421]]<|/det|>
In 1986 the Chernobyl nuclear power station in Ukraine suffered a meltdown.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 433, 920, 467]]<|/det|>
This caused background radiation in many countries, thousands of kilometres from Chernobyl, to increase.
